Columbia tailback Johnathan Reese rushed for 172 yards and 2 touchdowns and quarterback Jeff McCall threw for three scores and ran for another as the Lions defeated Fordham, 43-26, in their season opener last night at Wien Stadium. It was the most points for Columbia since a 44-0 victory over Fordham in 1972.
Columbia outscored the Rams, 22-0, in the second half, as Reese and the offensive line dominated.
Columbia put the game away midway through the fourth quarter. On fourth-and-3 from the Fordham 23, McCall hit flanker Jarel Cockburn on a perfect hitch-and-go pattern for the final touchdown.

Columbia got off to a hot start in a wild first half. Using a mix of short passes to the wide receivers and Reese's bruising running, it took the opening kickoff and marched 54 yards for a touchdown on McCall's 5-yard scramble.

Fordham (1-2) answered immediately, traveling 71 yards in eight plays to tie the score at 7-7. Alemayo Whyte dived in from the 1-yard line three plays after quarterback Mike Mucci connected with tight end Chris Harris for a 36-yard gain.

After Columbia punted on its next possession, the Fordham offense went to work again, marching 50 yards in nine plays. Tailback Arthur Gaskin sprinted untouched up the middle for a 9-yard touchdown, making the score 14-7.
The key play of the drive was a 10-yard run by Gaskin on third-and-1 on which he broke a tackle by Columbia's Kirby Mack in the backfield and scampered around right end to get the first down.

Columbia came right back, however. McCall connected with wide receiver Doug Peck on a 23-yard touchdown pass, with Peck leaping over defensive back Justin Logan to make an acrobatic catch and tie the score at 14-14.

Fordham fumbled the ensuing kickoff, and the Lions took advantage on the next play. McCall hit Cockburn on a wide receiver screen pass -- the Lions' fifth of the half -- and Cockburn took it 11 yards for a touchdown.

But Fordham scored the last 12 points of the half. On the Rams' next possession, Kirwin Watson plunged off tackle for a 2-yard touchdown. Brian Colsant missed the extra-point kick but made up for it by connecting on field goals of 34 and 40 yards before halftime, giving Fordham a 26-21 lead.

''I thought we moved the ball well all day, but we just couldn't stop anybody in the first half,'' Columbia Coach Ray Tellier said. ''In the second half, we got a couple of stops early on and we were able to continue what we were doing on offense as well.''
Columbia scored on its first possession of the second half. Reese's 9-yard touchdown run culminated an 80-yard drive that gave the Lions a 29-26 lead after the 2-point conversion.
The Lions struck again four minutes later. After an interception by free safety Phil Murray, Reese accounted for all 30 yards of Columbia's fifth touchdown march and scored on a 1-yard dive.
